title: Eddie Jones says Scotland have themselves to blame if they are knocked out of Rugby World Cup by typhoon
text:

Eddie Jones has insisted that Scotland will only have themselves to blame if they are knocked out of the Rugby World Cup as a result of Typhoon Hagibis.

Tournament organisers have already had to cancel England's match with France and New Zealand's final group game against Italy due to the approaching storm.

Scotland's decisive Pool A match against Japan could also be affected and is currently under review, along with Sunday's other matches.

If the meeting in Yokohama is called off, it is likely to result in Gregor Townsend's side being knocked out of the World Cup and the hosts would reach the quarter-finals.

However, England head coach Jones, whose side secured qualification with a game to spare, said he has limited sympathy for his Scottish counterpart and highlighted the need to prepare for the weather to play a factor.

(Image: NASA EARTH OBSERVATORY HANDOUT/EPA-EFE/REX)

"We've been talking about it all the time, about the possibility that this was going to happen - it's typhoon season," said Jones.

"You know what's going to happen. It's typhoon season here and you've got to be prepared for it.

"We had an idea it could happen and therefore you have to accumulate points in your games to put yourself in the right position in case that happened."

Jones said that his own team, who top Pool C with 17 points, wanted to make sure that their campaign was unaffected by external factors when they entered the tournament.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

"We just knew that there was the possibility of a game like this during the tournament so we just wanted to put ourselves in the best position we could," he added.

"This is supposed to be a big typhoon, so I don't see any other option that the organisers had.

"That's why we're not concerned at all about the comings and goings of it, we think it's the right decision."

With Scotland currently third in Pool A, behind Japan and Ireland, they need a win against the hosts to have any chance of reaching the next round.

(Image: Getty Images)

Coach Townsend says he is hopeful Sunday's will go ahead, while Scottish Rugby has called on organisers to prepare "contingency plans" to ensure the match is played.

A statement released on Thursday read: “We are in regular dialogue with World Rugby at all levels to work to ensure our fixture against Japan on Sunday can be played as planned. Public safety is the clear priority.

“With potential impact on our last Pool A fixture, Scottish Rugby fully expects contingency plans to be put in place to enable Scotland to contest for a place in the quarter-finals on the pitch, and will be flexible to accommodate this.”
description: Scotland's decisive Pool A match against Japan is currently under review as a result of Typhoon Hagibis
